2031. According to the Chandigarh Master Plan 2031, over bridges or flyovers are not recommended to be constructed in entire city of Chandigarh due to heritage considerations, since they impact the visual city scape, and cause inconvenience to the pedestrians.

Making observations on the project, the report of Parliamentary Standing Committee stated, “The Committee is aware that the matter of Zirakpur-Tribune Road is sub-judice. The Committee reiterates its recommendation given in previous report on demand for grants (2018-19) which stated the flyover project be undertaken with NHAI funds for early completion for improving traffic in and around Chandigarh,.”

“The Committee was given to understand that the UT Administration, in coordination with NHAI, is working on this project from Zirakpur to Tribune Chowk (flyover) road section for better traffic management. It recommends that all projects undertaken must be completed expeditiously,” the report stated.

Following the HC’s directions, the Administration had held public hearing on December 23 last year, in which 53 of the 78 participants had opposed the flyover. Seven persons were even called for detailed deliberations on alternative proposals mooted by them.

However, the Administration had recently rejected all the seven shortlisted alternative proposals to the Tribune flyover.

Notably, the UT Technical Committee constituted to explore alternatives to the project, had recently recommended Administration to again seek Union Ministry’s opinion on the project.

However, the Administration has decided to take up the matter in the meeting of UT Administrator’s Advisory Council, constituted to advise the higher authorities on developmental issues and policy matters.

Contentious flyover project

The 1.6 km flyover is proposed to be built from near the GMCH-32 roundabout up to the railway overbridge on Dakshin Marg after passing over Tribune Chowk. Punjab Governor and UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore had laid the foundation stone of the Rs 184 crore project in March last year. It was proposed as a solution to the traffic congestion at the stretch of Tribune Chowk. More than 1.43 lakh vehicles cross the rotaries of Dakshin Marg and Purva Marg near Sector-31 Tribune Chowk daily.

Regarding the progress of the flyover at Tribune Chowk, the Administration submitted to the Parliamentary Committee that the work has been approved by the Union Ministry of Road Transport & Highways in letter dated February 11, 2019 amounting to Rs 183.74 crore.

Accordingly, the bids for the work were invited by the UT Engineering Department. Subsequently, the letter of acceptance was issued to the lowest agency M/s DRAIPL-DMR Builders (JV) amounting to Rs 137.40 crores. Meanwhile, a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) was filed in the Punjab and Haryana High Court regarding the cutting of trees and the matter is sub-judice.

Title: Sukhbir seeks action against cops who assaulted teachers
Article:
Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) president Sukhbir Badal on Wednesday demanded immediate registration of a criminal case against police personnel who launched a brutal assault on peacefully protesting unemployed teachers in Patiala to please their political masters as well as action against those who ordered this barbaric action.

“It has come to light in the media that some police officers, including the Patiala Superintendent of Police (City), beat up the unemployed teachers mercilessly without any provocation sorely to earn brownie points,” said Sukhbir.

He said: “With senior officers leading the charge against the youth, other cops also took the cue that there was a direct order from the very top to teach a lesson to the unemployed teachers for daring to march towards the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh’s residence…This resulted in injuries to a dozen persons, including women with policemen pulling them with their hair and misbehaving with them. The brutality was such that two youth even jumped into the Bhakra canal.”

Sukhbir said that instead of taking action against the police personnel, the Congress Government registered cases against the “victims of the merciless assault” by registering cases against 70 unemployed teachers.

Stating that it was actions like these which were signs of a dictatorial regime, the SAD president demanded that cases being withdrawn immediately.

He also demanded registration of a criminal case against the SP (City) as well as other cops involved in this gruesome attack besides action against those who ordered it.

Asking the Chief Minister not to play with the lives of youth, Sukhbir said that “first you failed to implement your ‘Ghar Ghar Naukari’ promise, then you lied that 12 lakh youth had been given employment when your own Government submitted a written reply in the Vidhan Sabha that only 34,000 youth had been given government jobs in three years”.

“Now when the youth are demanding their legitimate right and only asking that the 12,000 vacant posts of ETT and TET be filled, you are launching your police force against them,” he said.

SAD president said that the Congress Government had proved that it did not have any intention to recruit qualified candidates who had passed the TET examination by advertising 1,664 posts even when there were 12,000 vacancies.

“What new posts will you create when you are not even filling vacant posts,” he asked adding that SAD would launch a sustained campaign soon to force the government to fill all vacant posts as well as create new ones to provide employment to the youth.

Title: Soon, Memorial dedicated to terror victims in Punjab
Article:
Another memorial, dedicated to those laying down their lives during dark days of terrorism, would soon come up in Punjab. “The people of Punjab would always remember the sacrifices made by the martyrs who laid down their lives during the dark decade of terrorism in the State,” said Khanna MLA Gurkirat Singh Kotli while unfurling a ‘Flag of Unity’ at Tolemajra village in SAS Nagar district.

The memorial would come up adjacent to the ‘Flag of Unity’, installed in the memory of Narpinder Pal Singh Prince who was martyred on March 11, 1992. The flag's pole is 100 feet while its size is 30X20 feet. “The names of those who laid down their lives in terror days in Punjab will be engraved on the Memorial,” said Kotli.

The MLA said that the State is witnessing peaceful atmosphere only because of the untold number of sacrifices made by the people from all sections of the society who opposed extremist tendencies tooth and nail.

“It is the responsibility of the present generation to preserve the legacy bestowed by the martyrs,” he said.

Title: 11 taken ill taking spurious tea, 1 in ICU
Article:
At least 11 people, including a woman, were taken ill in Bhograi block in Baleswar district after consuming spurious tea in morning on Wednesday. One of them was shifted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of the District Headquarters Hospital (DHH) as his condition became critical.

The incident occurred in village Ransingpur under Kanthabhaunri GP.

According to sources, the affected were the guests of one Santosh Pradhan of the village who had come to attend the wedding of his son.

Reports added that while preparing tea, the cook inadvertently poured pesticides instead of tea leaf. The poisonous tea was served and consumed by the victims. They had nausea, head reeling then vomiting.

They were initially admitted in the local hospital before being taken to the DHH. The attending doctors said all were stable after treatment though one of them had to be shifted to the ICU.

Title: Cong walks out of HP Assembly
Article:
The opposition Congress on Wednesday walked out from Himachal Pradesh Assembly after expressing their dissatisfaction over Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur's reply on pay anomalies of outsource employees.

The Chief Minister, however, said the opposition party was "frustrated" by the latest developments in Madhya Pradesh where their leader, Jyotiraditya Scindia, quit the party and joined the BJP.

Speaking during the question hour in the ongoing Budget session in the State Assembly, Thakur accused the Congress of making walkouts a "routine affair".

The Congress legislators walked out from the House when the chief minister held the previous Congress Government responsible for exploitation of outsource employees.

The previous Congress Government did nothing to regularise the outsource employees during its tenure of five years, but promised to regularise them right before the last Assembly elections in 2017, Thakur said.

Earlier responding to Barsar Congress MLA Inder Dutt Lakhanpal's question, the Chief Minister informed the House, "Recruitment and promotion rules do not apply for outsource employees as they are not Government employees.

They are employees of service provider companies with whom their agreements have been made." As per the agreement, service provider companies are bound to pay outsource employees minimum wages, he added.

The State Government is trying to ensure that the outsource employees are not exploited, the BJP leader said, adding provisions have been made to provide travel allowance, daily allowance and medical leave to them besides the provision of maternity leave. It has also been made mandatory that the outsource employees be provided monthly salary slips, the chief minister added.

SOLAN VARSITY ASSISTANT REGISTRAR HELD IN FAKE DEGREE SCAM, SAYS CM

The Himachal Pradesh Police has arrested the assistant registrar of Solan-based Manav Bharti University in an alleged fake degree scam.

Giving a statement in the State Assembly during the Budget session on Wednesday, Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur told the House that it was evident from the documents seized from the Solan university that they were playing with students' future by issuing fake degrees for long.

Assistant Registrar Munish Goel was arrested on March 8 and remanded in three-day police custody, he said, adding that three FIRs were lodged against the university on March 3, 7 and 8 under various sections of the IPC, including cheating charges, at the Solan's Dharampur police station. Thakur further stated that an FIR was also registered against Una-based Indus University at the Haroli police station on March 9.

Stating that all four FIRs were being thoroughly investigated, the CM said a complaint received against APG University of Shimla was also being probed by a special investigation team (SIT) of the Crime Investigation Department (CID). The CM said the State police seized 305 detailed mark cards, 15 degrees, computer hard disc, laptop, pen drive, stamps and several other documents during its raid on March 6 at the Solan university.

Thakur said police also searched MBU owner Raj Kumar Rana's Madhav University in Rajasthan's Mount Abu and sealed its administrative complex after seizing 1,376 blank degrees, 14 stamps, four despatch registers, 50 migration certificates, 319 blank detailed mark cards and several other documents.

The CM said one of the three FIRs against the Solan university was lodged on March 3 on the complaint of Haryana''s Charkhi Dadri resident Mamta, in which she alleged that she was given a fake degree.

Earlier, Leader of Opposition Mukesh Agnihotri on February 27 had pointed out that there were reports about the involvement of two private universities of the state in a fake degree scam.

Replying to it, Education Minister Suresh Bhardwaj had then said that the University Grants Commission (UGC) had received a complaint alleging that 18 private universities, including two in Himachal Pradesh, were selling fake degrees.

The State police was probing the matter and strict action will be taken if any university is found selling fake degrees, he had added.

Title: 3 cops hurt in mob attack in Baleswar
Article:
Three policemen were injured in an attack by locals in the Khantapada area of Baleswar district on Tuesday. The injured were rushed to District Headquarters Hospital with head injuries.

As per reports, a group clash broke out near a liquor counter at Gopalpur Chhak in Khantapada. After receiving information, police reached the spot and resorted to a lathicharge which further fuelled the tension.

Some elderly persons intervened into the matter to find an amicable solution. But instead of supporting the move, the police attempted to take the mediators into its custody. Following this, locals became belligerent and attacked the police officials.

An eyewitness said the group clash started following an argument over consumption of alcohol. But the situation went out of control when the cops intervened in the matter.

Title: S’garh girl sold in Delhi by boyfriend rescued
Article:
A young girl of Sundargarh district, who was allegedly sold off by her boyfriend in New Delhi has been rescued by a social organisation.

As per reports, one Sankar Bage had taken the girl Balmati Moil hailing from Kucheita in Chandiposh area of the district to Delhi on March 3 on the pretext of marrying her. The girl’s cousin Nirmanti Tirkey is alleged to have connived with Sankar and persuaded the victim to go to Delhi.

In Delhi, Shankar abandoned her at an office and fled from the spot. Later, the girl learnt that her friend had sold her off.

When she managed to contact her parents and informed them about her ordeal up, they lodged a complaint with the Chandiposh police in this connection on March 5.

However, as police did not cooperate in rescuing the girl they sought the help of a social activist Chandmani Sandil, who contacted a Delhi-based NGO for help. Finally, the girl was rescued and she reached Rourkela on Tuesday evening.

“As per the FIR, we have registered case. We are now recording the statement of victim girl and we are investigating the case. We are searching for accused Shankar and Nirmanti,” said Chandiposh police station IIC Satish Nayak.

Title: 3 killed as bike hits tree in Dhenkanal
Article:
Three persons were killed after a motorcycle by which they were travelling hit a roadside tree at Kaimati Chhak in Dhenkanal district on Tuesday afternoon.

The deceased were identified as Shubra Saswat Routray, Dharmananda Dehuri from Kaimati and Kailash Sahu from Achhanda village.

After celebrating Holi, the three friends attended a feast. Later, they were returning home by a motorcycle when the two-wheeler met with a mishap at Kaimati Chhak. An eyewitness said the motorcycle driver lost control over the vehicle and hit a tree.

The three injured were rushed to the District Headquarters Hospital where doctors declared them dead.

In another incident, a youth died after being run over by a truck in the Soro area in Baleswar district on Tuesday morning. The deceased, identified as Narendra Jena from Mahumuhana village under the Soro police station. Narendra was on his way by a motorcycle to buy colour to celebrate Holi.

Narendra was caught in a fight between three bulls on the road. Suddenly one of the bulls ran towards him and threw him away with its horns. In the meantime, a truck coming from opposite direction crushed Narendra injuring him critically.

He was rushed to the hospital where doctors declared him dead.

Title: 4 BJD candidates file nominations for RS polls
Article:
The four candidates of the BJD on Wednesday filed their nomination papers for elections to as many Rajya Sabha seats from the State.

Subash Singh, Chairperson of the Odisha Construction Workers Welfare Board; Munna Khan, Advisor to the Government on Minority Affairs; Sujit Kumar, Advisor of Special Development Council (SDC); and Mamata Mahanta, a member of the women wing of the BJD in Mayurbhanj district, filed their nominations at the Assembly Conference Hall here in the presence of party supremo and Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik.

The nominations were filed before the State Assembly Secretary Dasarathi Satapathy, who is also the Returning Officer for the purpose.

The BJD with 113 members in the 147-seat Assembly is all set to win all four Rajya Sabha seats as Leader of Opposition (BJP) Pradipta Kumar Naik said his party would not field any candidate as it does not have the “required number” to elect one to the Upper House of Parliament.

The Congress, which has only nine MLAs, will also not participate in the polls.

The last date of filing of nominations is March 13. Scrutiny of the nominations is on March 16. Last date for withdrawal of candidatures is March 18. The date of poll is March 26; and voting will take place between 9 am to 4 pm. Votes will be counted on the same day at 5 pm followed by announcement of results.

Title: Gambling den busted in Ganjam, 10 held
Article:
Police busted a gambling den near the Subarneswara temple under the Aska police station of Ganjam district on Tuesday afternoon.

Acting on specific inputs, a police team raided a house near the temple and arrested 10 gamblers.

The accused were identified as Chittaranjan Swain, Mochiram Nahak, Subash Swain, Raju Sahu, Rabindra Patra, Sushant Kumar Pradhan, Mangalu Jena, Samir Sahu, Bulu Jena and Sanjay Naik. They were caught while gambling on the occasion of Holi.

Also, the police seized Rs 1,41,400 cash, 10 motorcycles, 10 mobile phones, playing cards and food packets were seized from the spot.

Later, all the accused will be forwarded to court.

During Dussehra last year, police had registered more than 20 cases and arrested more than 100 persons on charges of gambling.

Title: Youth dies in hit & run accident
Article:
A youth died when an unidentified vehicle hit his motorcycle near Kanjara village on the National Highway-55 in Angul district on Tuesday night.

The deceased was identified as Sumant Biswal (28), a resident of Bimalabeda village under the Jarapada police station. According to reports, the incident occurred at around 11pm when Sumant was returning to home from Jarapada by his motorcycle. An unidentified vehicle coming from opposite direction hit the motorcycle and sped away following which the youth was knocked over and died on the spot.

The commuters travelling on the route informed local police about the accident. On receiving information, the Jarapada police reached the spot and sent the body for the postmortem.

Title: Haryana to add 4,500 buses in transport fleet
Article:
Haryana Transport Minister Mool Chand Sharma on Wednesday said that soon the State transport fleet will be increased to 4500 buses from 3600 at present.

"After the formation of the present Government, 150 minibusses have arrived while 130 pink buses are being run for women," Sharma said while speaking to reporters.

He said that out of 510 buses under the km scheme, about 80 percent were plying while the remaining 20 percent buses would also start running by the end of this month. In addition, 18 Volvo buses will soon be added to the fleet.

Similarly, the purchase of 867 buses has been approved which starts running by May-June.

The Transport Minister said that km scheme is completely in the interest of the common man and that the shortage of buses will soon be met.

On the threats of the employees union of the roadways, he said that the employee unions had said that the Government wanted to abolish the roadways and they demanded that there should be no layoff of employees.

The government assured them that neither would the employees would be laid off nor would the number of buses in the fleet be reduced, he added.

He said that the State Government has recruited about 5200 employees in the Transport Department.

Title: BJP threatens stir over BeMC tax hikes
Article:
The Ganjam BJP has threatened to launch a stir against the plan of the Brahmapur Municipal Corporation (BeMC) to impose various taxes and hike the holding tax rates for the residents.

In a memorandum to Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik through the RDC Southern Range, the party demanded action against officials in BeMC who collected water cess in excess of the stipulated rate and flouted the rule by not depositing the same with the PHED.

Similarly, it alleged that whenever the Government took a decision to hike rates of taxes on land sale and purchase, benchmark valuation, holding tax, etc, it first implemented the same in Brahmapur. It lamented the misutilisation of crores of rupees under Swachh Bharat and protested the plan to collect Rs 600 from each household for maintaining hygiene. The party demanded special funds from the CM for development of Brahmapur muck like Bhubaneswar, Cuttack and Puri, besides development of the MKCG Medical College and Hospital. The memorandum was signed by former Brahmapur MLA candidate Kanhu Charan Pati, Gopinath Panda, Binayaka Rath, Madan Patra, S Rani and Sunil Kuar Sahu among others.

Title: 14 killed in Holi-related mishaps in State
Article:
As many as 14 persons lost their lives in connection with Holi-related incidents on Tuesday either in road mishaps or getting drowned in water bodies across the State.

In Cuttack district, four youths drowned in Kathajodi and Chitroptala rivers. A Class IX student and another youth went missing while taking bath in Kathajodi river. Later, the Fire Service personnel rescued the two persons and admitted them to the SCB Medical College Hospital in critical condition where doctors declared them dead.

A student of Bahugram Junior College, Shubham Prateek Dash drowned in Chitroptala river in the afternoon while taking bath after Holi celebrations.

In another incident, three youths drowned in Badanala reservoir of Rayagada district while bathing after playing Holi. Another youth was rescued in critical condition from the reservoir.

One Aditya Naik drowned in Indravati river in Nabarangpur town while taking bath along with three friends. While Aditya went missing, three of his friends managed to reach the shore. After a two-hour-long operation Fire Service personnel and ODRAF team fished out Aditya’s body.

Shubham Samal (14), a resident of Rairakhol Railway Colony in Sambalpur district drowned in a stream while bathing. A youth Rama Swami (25) met a watery grave in Mahendratanya river in Paralakhemundi of Gajapati district while taking bath along with friends after Holi celebrations.

In another mishap, three persons lost their lives in Dhenkanal district when their motorcycle hit a roadside tree in afternoon. They were returning home after attending a feast organised as part of Holi celebrations. In Baleswar district, a youth from Mahumuhana village under the Soro police station was run over by a truck while going to the nearby market on his motorcycle to buy color for Holi.

Title: UT mulls to cap number of occupants in PGs
Article:
After last month’s fire tragedy at an unregistered paying guest accommodation in Sector 32 here that claimed three young lives, the Chandigarh Administration is now mulling to put a cap on number of occupants that would be allowed to live in a paying guest accommodation in the city.

Another proposal has been mooted to fix number of rent deeds to be allowed in a house.

Recently, certain new provisions were added in the revised PG policy of Chandigarh which included mandatory fire clearance, annual renewal of license, indemnity certificate from PG owners. The Administration had also decided not to exempt the requirement of house owners staying in the PG accommodation.

As per the rules framed by UT Administration, a PG facility can operate only in a house with an area of at least 7.5 marla. It is mandatory to get it registered and thereon pay commercial rates for water and electricity.

Also, PGs are not allowed to run their own kitchen in the accommodation. “A proposal has been chalked out to put a cap on the number of occupants to be allowed to live in a PG facility here.

The number will be decided as per the area of the accommodation. At present, the minimum usable area for one paying guest is 50 sq. ft,” said a senior officer of Chandigarh administration.

He said that the clause of rent deed is often misused by the owners who do not register their houses as PG facilities. Considering this, we have also proposed to fix number of rent deeds to be allowed in a house, the officer added.

Title: ‘Jan Ausadhi boon for K’jhar tribals’
Article:
The Jan Ausadhi, a scheme of the Central Government to provide essential generic medicines to common man, is growing popular in tribal district like Keonjhar.

The Jan Ausadhi Kendras across the district are providing medicines at very low cost for which people prefer to buy their medicines from these stores. As a result, health services have become more affordable and assessable to citizens, told speakers during the National Jan Ausadhi Divas observed here.

Doctors, people’s representatives, journalists and patients spoke about their personal experiences as to how they got benefitted by the scheme.

Sasmita Pradhan, a women entrepreneur running a Jan Ausadhi Kendra, cited many examples of patients who were surprised by the low cost medicines. Dr Sanjeev Ota and Dr Srikanth Soren, educationist Basant Dani, Malaya Mohapatra, Rajalaxmi Swain and Kendujhar MLA Mohan Charan Majhi also briefed about the benefits of the scheme with instances.

Since the sales are increasing, to cater to the demand, more stores are planned to be opened in the district in rural areas and promote health among citizens, MLA Majhi told.

Title: Min urged to develop Khuludi waterfall
Article:
The five-day Malyagiri festival came to close on March 9. Culture and Tourism Minister Jyotiprakas Panigrahi was the chief guest, while other dignitaries present were Talcher MLA Brajakishore Pradhan and Sub-Collector Pallahara Ajit Pradhan.

Local MLA Mukesh Pal urged Minister Panigrahi to develop the Khuludi waterfall and second Chilika of the State in Pallahara. The first MLA of Pallahara Mrutyunjaya Pal, first IAS Udayanath Sahu and first IFS Harinarayan Sahu were felicitated on the occasion. Sub-Collector Pradhan gave a vote of thanks. A cultural show ensued at the end.

Title: Protests at old site illegal from today
Article:
Despite the notice issued by Dehradun City Magistrate Anuradha Pal to vacate the protest site near Parade Ground, the protesters did not leave the site claiming it to be the State Government’s plan to suppress the voice of protesters. On the other hand Pal stated that conducting protest in the old protest site would be illegal from Thursday as the approval to protest in the old protest site is revoked.

Recently, the protesters at the protest site near Parade Ground were issued notice to shift their respective protests in the new protest site at Adhoiwala after Holi. However, no protest has been shifted to the new protest site by protestors so far. While talking to The Pioneer, Pal said that the notice was served to the protesting groups in the old protest site to shift their protest in the new site by March 11.

The permission to protest at the old protest site has been revoked and if the protest is not shifted then necessary steps will be taken against the protestors. “For now, we are just appealing the protestors to evict the site on their own. The approval granted for protests at the old site has already been revoked and if anybody is found to conduct any kind of protest at the old site, it will be against the law,” said Pal.

However, the protesters are not ready to vacate the old protest site as they consider it the government’s plot to smother their ongoing protests. “Government is sending us to a location where no one can see or hear people like us who are protesting against their oppression.

We will not budge from this place until the government annul the forest guard recruitment exam,” said one of the protesting members of Uttarakhand Unemployed Organisation (UUO) Suryakant Arya. According to one of the protesting members of Gairsain Rajdhani Nirman Abhiyan (GRNA) Manoj Dhyani, the administration has not made any arrangements in the new protest site like sanitation facilities, electricity or drinking water. Several diseases are spreading these days like Coronavirus and the administration is sending protestors to the location where hygienic conditions are quite poor, said Dhyani.

However, Pal said that the arrangement to provide all the basic facilities have been made in the new protest site near Adhoiwala.

The basic facilities that include mobile toilets, electricity, and drinking water are made available for the protestors said Pal. Pal also stated that it is important to shift the protest site to the new location because the construction under the Smart City Project will begin there soon.

In the meantime, delegations of an organisational and public group met the chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat regarding the shifting of the protesting site to Adhoiwala stating this move to be against the system of democracy.

Title: Woman thrashed by hooligans in city
Article:
In a case of brazen hooliganism, a woman was manhandled and kicked by a group of miscreants in public in broad daylight at Bindusagar Road in Old Town under the Lingaraj police station here on Tuesday.

A CCTV footage of the incident shows the woman identified as Sabita Sethi (38) being thrashed, manhandled and kicked by six to seven youths in full public glare.

However, the passersby turned silent spectators instead of intervening and rescuing the woman. Later, the video of the incident went viral on social media. As per the complaint lodged with the Lingaraj police on Wednesday, Sabita’s family had a dispute with members of Taranga Club for long.

In the evening, when Sabita went to drop her son to his tuition classes, some club members came in inebriated condition and started hurling abuses over the old land dispute and pelted stones at her house.

Sabita also alleged that, the anti-socials also attacked her father and uncle besides abusing them in filthy language. Though she has lodged a police complaint in this regard, no action has been taken yet and the accused are still moving scot-free.

Title: General, OBC staff to intensify stir from today
Article:
The Uttarakhand general and OBC employees association would intensify its strike from Thursday by bringing the essential services in the ambit of the strike. On Wednesday, hectic parleys between the office bearers of the general and OBC association and different employees organisations took place to discuss the modalities of the strike.

The general secretary of the association, Virendra Singh Gusain told The Pioneer that 60- 70 percent of essential services would cease to operate from Thursday. On the appeal of chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat in which he has requested the employees to take back their strike in the interest of the state, Gusain said that time of appeal has ended and the chief minister should take a decision on the issue.

Meanwhile on Thursday, the association constituted committees for monitoring and inculcating enthusiasm among the employees in different districts. On single point demand of implementing the order of Supreme Court (SC), the general and OBC employees are on strike from March 2.

It is pertinent to mention here that the SC on February 7 while hearing a Special Leave Petition (SLP) of Uttarakhand government had said that the states are not bound to provide reservation in promotions and reservation is not a fundamental right.

The SLP was filed by the Uttarakhand government against the Uttarakhand High Court (HC) order in Gyanchand Vs state case. This order has brought a sharp schism among the employees on caste lines. The general and OBC employees want that there should be no reservation in promotion while the SC and ST want that the benefit of reservation should be extended to them in promotions also.

Title: Farmer’s income to be Rs 96K by ’22-‘23
Article:
The State Government has adopted the Agriculture Budget and is implementing various State and Centre-sponsored projects to double the annual per capita income of farmers to Rs 95,976 by 2022-23, informed Agriculture and Farmers’ Empowerment Minister Dr Arun Kumar Sahoo in the State Assembly on Wednesday.

In response to a question of BJP MLA Mohan Charan Majhi, the Minister said that the Union Government has calculated per capital income of farmers of Odisha at Rs 47,988 in 2015-16 as per the 70 survey report of the National Sample Survey Organisation (NSSO) and has set a target to double the farmers’ annual income by 2022-23.

To achieve the target, the special Agriculture Budget is being implemented and various State and Central projects implemented. Crop insurance, development of agriculture farms, Biju Krushak Yalyan Yojana, organic farming, KALIA Yojana are among 34 schemes being implemented by the State Government. As many as 13 projects are being executed by the Centre.

Title: 3 varsities to come up next year
Article:
The State Government has proposals for establishing Kalahandi University’ at Bhawanipatna, Rajendra University at Balangir and Madhusudan Law University at Cuttack during 2020-21 academic year.

Higher Education Minister Arun Kumar Sahoo informed this in the State Assembly in response to a question of BJD member Bhupinder Singh on Wednesday.

The Minister said the Kalahandi University would start functions from June 1, 2020. There was no budgetary provision made for this university in 2019-20. However, Rs 58 lakh has been allocated for the university in 2020-21 Budget. The allocated amount includes Rs 18 lakh for general expenditure and Rs 40 lakh for payment of salaries.

Title: Why Naveen is adorably invincible in Odisha
Article:
Naveen Patnaik has proven himself to be the most popular Chief Minister in India. Even late West Bengal Chief Minister Jyoti Basu from the Marxist fold, who held a record for the longest-serving CM, did not have the invincibility Naveen commands today. Basu had a chequered graph -- rising and falling in number of election victory seats; and he never enjoyed the mass adulation like Naveen, whose popularity graph is just incredibly steady.

This story is not meant to eulogise Naveen. What makes him so strong and invincible is an amusing case in point. When Naveen first showed up as legendary Biju Patnaik’s least-known younger son, people imagined he would only play puppet in the hands of rogue politicians who wanted to encash on the Biju legacy. Bijubabu was deified much before he died. He was considered the only politician who meant as well as did good works for the State. So, anyone from his family would do the magic in the game of popular politics.

Naveen agreed to take over, but he had made his mind clear before the self-serving rogues that he would work for the State’s development by serving the poorest of the poor in a strictly disciplined manner. He knew seasoned bureaucrats would be the best community to guide him properly, without which the political gangsters would eat up the State along with him. So came in Pyari Mohan Mahapatra, the long-time trusted lieutenant to Bijubabu, who was inducted as principal guru and guide. Thereafter, how political detractors got fixed or axed is only ordinary history by now.

Naveen has made sure right from the beginning that politicians, especially the self-serving, loudmouths listened to gutsy, spotless and honest bureaucrats, particularly from the IAS cadre, who would determine what is important for the State, design people-friendly schemes and call all critical shots. The political executive would only act as the front and ensure that the people benefitted on all counts. The masses got to know this special arrangement quite early and are pretty much happy as the going is good. Further, any bureaucrat who is too willing to take the extra mile is naturally closer to the boss than others who are not in a position to remain engaged in a glued manner due to personal circumstances. Detractors and opponents keep ranting about Naveen running a bureaucracy in Odisha because they fail to realise the fact that bureaucrats only guide the political executive critically and do nothing more. Today, the political class, by and large dumb in head and populist, feel safe to be guided by the prudent bureaucrats by keeping away from risks of law and rule violation.

Naveen hasn’t changed his style of functioning once in all these twenty years. Good governance is his primary objective. For this, all the trusted core group officials have been asked to keep him updated on all fronts and take his final orders to carry out without fail.

There is another big reason why Naveen is enormously popular.The opposing parties including BJP and Congress have never been able to match his popularity as they have no charismatic leader in their midst. The BJP has lately made some insignificant, flimsy impact due to Modi's dramatic moves like Article 370 scrapping and Balakote strikes. Obviously, the BJP has emerged as a popular alternative because of terrible Congress blunders on countless fronts. The Odisha Congress party has been reduced to an intangible idea only. Infighting has never stopped, even during their worst times. The incumbent president has lost everything, political seat, face and reputation. He is just a skeletal symbol of a vanquished outfit. The Odisha Congress is fast degenerating into a bitter episode in pages of the State’s political history. Even in Madhya Pradesh, the frontline leaders are out to topple the Kamal Nath Government by defecting into the BJP as they have to survive as politicians.

But Naveen is gaining in popularity by the day. He has been particularly adored for a few specific reasons: he is unmarried; has the simplest-ever lifestyle; speaks only when necessary and that too in two or three sentences; never speaks ill of even the worst enemy or detractor no matter how vitriolic or scandalous he or she is. His legendary father, despite his immeasurable popularity, did not enjoy such love and respect as Naveen is basking in the popularity glory today.

For the first time in Odisha's political history, mainstream career politicians are expected to behave well with the people and do as told by the well-meaning bureaucrats who go by the rulebook in hand.

Even while choosing candidates for elections, Naveen puts his lieutenants to do a thorough due diligence on the antecedents of the potential candidates and chooses those who are adored and respected by the masses. A few exceptions occur though, only when political compulsions are extremely high.

His latest choice of Rajya Sabha candidates is superbly made on accurate calculations. Only those highly qualified or people’s guys with a heart and mind for the poor are eventually chosen. The latest selected candidates include Sujit Kumar who has been an international bureaucrat after having been at the best universities of the world including Harvard and serving at the most prestigious global institutions like the World Economic Forum, Davos in Switzerland. He has been part of several flagship programmes and schemes of the government as an experienced, highly exposed professional. Subas Singh, once a firebrand unionist, has been a hardcore people’s leader for quite some time. He was one of the frontline spokespersons for the BJD. Munna Khan, a Biju-devotee movie idol and a popular leader from the minority community has been going places for long. And most admirably, Naveen chose a nondescript woman social worker called MamataMahanta who has been working for the poorest of the poor women of the tribal Mayurbhanj district since a decade without expecting any reward. She is from a very backward Kudumi community found only in Keonjhar and Mayurbhanj districts. She has been closely working with hundreds of Self-Help Groups that promote socioeconomic empowerment through micro enterprises and thrift activities. By the time World Woman’s Day was around, Mahanta got her due recognition from Naveen. No wonder why Naveen is so popular among the people.

Lastly, on this day in March 1930, Mahatma Gandhi's Dandi March had commenced. Seventy-eight people had walked with the Mahatma across 240 km between his ashram in Sabarmati and the coastal village of Dandi. The march was an act of civil resistance against the British law that banned production of salt by poor people for livelihood.

Naveen, a staunch Gandhi follower, has invariably been advocating for inclusion of ‘nonviolence’ in the Preamble of the Indian Constitution, and logically so.

Title: End strike in interest of State: CM Rawat
Article:
The Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat has made an appeal to the Uttarakhand General and OBC employees association to take back its strike in the interest of the state.

He said that said that the threat of Coronavirus (COVID- 19) is looming large over the country and in such a situation the employees should not remain on strike. In an appeal the chief secretary of Uttarakhand, Utpal Kumar Singh has also said that though no case of Coronavirus has been reported from the state, efforts on war scale are being done to combat the disease.

He added that the performance and outcome budget by the departments would be presented in the assembly and the strike during such conditions is creating challenging situation before the state administration.

Singh said that in view of the all round development and the interest of the state, the strike should end.

Title: CM should clear uncertainty: Pritam Singh
Article:
The Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) president Pritam Singh has said that the Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat should clear uncertainty over the issue of reservation in promotions. Talking with the media persons at the state headquarters of the Congress party here on Wednesday, Singh said that the Uttarakhand government has failed miserably to prevent the employees from going on strike.

“A deep furrow has got created between the general caste and SC, ST employees which would affect the development of the state. It is the responsibility of the government to coordinate with the employees. Our party has always taken both the reserved and unreserved categories along. The chief minister should clear uncertainty on the issue,’’ he said.

Title: Modern bus port to come up at Khan Nagar
Article:
With a move to decongest the Millennium City of Cuttack and provide better service to the citizens, the State Government has decided to establish an ultramodern bus port near Khan Nagar.

In order to survey the area and take on-the-spot decision, 5T Secretary VK Pandian along with a team of officials visited the area in the wee hours of March 10.

Pandian was happy to take stock of the matter as the State Government will soon take up the job on a priority basis.

Works Secretary Krishan Kumar presented the model for development and structures to come up in the area.

Dr Kumar along with his team earlier made a survey and assessed the requirement, said sources. CMD OSRTC Arun Bothra, RDC Central Division Anil Samal among others were present. The OSRTC will be developing the Cuttack bus stand to next level as Badambadi bus stand is unable to cater to the growing requirement of the public. It has not only been very much congested but also during peak hours, it is posing a serious problem for movement of vehicles and passengers.

While plans are afoot to improve the Millennium City in a big way with world class medical college and hospital in SCB, setting up of ring road and other facilities, establishing an ultra modern bus stand is also on cards.

Earlier, there was a plan for inter State bus port at Gopalpur and accordingly, the State Government agreed to provide land. Somehow, it has not taken off and now move is on to set up a new bus port near Khan Nagar, while acquiring some more areas for the facility.

Title: No percolation of leachate into groundwater in Sheeshambada: MCD
Article:
Denying all the allegations of the locals of Sheeshambada about the untreated leachate getting mixed with the groundwater in the area, the chief municipal health officer at Municipal Corporation of Dehradun (MCD) Dr Kailash Joshi said that proper arrangements are made at the solid waste management and recycling plant in Sheeshambada to ensure the proper treatment of leachate.

The locals of Sheeshambada are incessantly speaking about the improper treatment of leachate at the waste management plant which is allegedly mixing with groundwater and polluting it.

According to them, the polluted water is coming through the taps at their homes too and those who use tap water are compelled to use it for drinking. However, Joshi has rejected all the allegations regarding the pollution of groundwater due to the improper treatment of leachate. According to him, around Rs six crore was spent on the layering of the surface of the plant to ensure that no percolation of leachate occurs during its treatment. Besides, the proper treatment is being done through Leachate Treatment Plant (LTP) so there is no way of its getting mixed with groundwater and polluting it, said Joshi.

Meanwhile, the residents of Sheeshambada warned of protest outside the residence of the Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat besides commencing a campaign in which the local women will go door to door to aware people about the misconduct of the government in their area.

Title: Snoring can be a noisy killer if untreatedDehradun
Article:
March 13 is observed as World Sleep Day. Ahead of this this occasion, Dr Lav Kush Chaudhary, senior consultant, Respiratory Medicine and Sleep Specialist at Synergy Institute of Medical Sciences explains, how this noisy killer can be deadly. Snoring is a sign of further complication in human system, if snoring gets louder including the symptoms such as gasps for air or interrupted breathing, it should be immediately checked. There are basically two types of snores, one is just a rhythmic type of snore, and usually the volume level stays about the same.

The other type of snoring, which about 75 per cent of people who snore will have, is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA is a potentially serious sleep disorder. It causes breathing to repeatedly stop and start during sleep.There are several types of sleep apnea, but the most common is obstructive sleep apnea. Nearly one billion people globally are suffering from obstructive sleep apnea.

Snoring in simplest terms is vibration of tissue, the most obvious tissue that would vibrate when somebody is snoring is the uvula, or the back of the palette that hangs down. During sleep, throat muscles relaxes, sometimes the tongue falls back in the mouth and partially blocks. The greater the obstruction in the airway, the louder snoring gets. Bigger health concerns involve severe snoring and when the airway collapses completely, causing obstruction of airflow, followed by people waking up just enough to start breathing again. However, people with sleep apnea typically don’t wake to consciousness and are often unaware of it.

Obesity also contributes because the body has to work harder at breathing in sleep. Another factor might be that the nose is obstructed, tonsils could play some role, although, it’s less frequent, but children can have snoring and sleep apnea.

Excessive daytime sleepiness, observed episodes of stopped breathing during sleep, abrupt awakenings accompanied by gasping or choking, awakening with a dry mouth or sore throat, morning headache, difficulty concentrating during the day, experiencing mood changes, such as depression or irritability, high blood pressure, night-time sweating, decreased libido etc are symptoms of OSA.

With OSA there’s increased risk of heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and obesity. Further, frequent bathroom breaks at night due to decrease in the oxygen level actually effect kidneys, followed by poor memory, difficulty in concentrating and co-morbidities such high blood sugar levels and blood pressure.

OSA patients may experience worse breathing problems after major surgery, especially after being sedated.

Continuous Positive Airway Pressure therapy (CPAP), is a gold standard treatment for sleep apnea. Doctors now can set a range of pressure, and the device detects when a patient needs a higher level.

However, with new research and development machines have become smart enough to know when the patient needs a higher pressure, if patient is on their back or in REM sleep.

Moreover, there has been drastic innovation in masks, earlier the masks were bulky and claustrophobic however, with time masks have become smaller and fit more comfortably which hardly effects patient normal activities, including reading and watching television.

Along with CPAP therapy it is also advisable to avoid smoking, alcohol and muscle relaxant before bedtime and keep weight controlled. The other treatment options are surgery and oral appliances.

Title: Penalty to be levied on defaulters from April
Article:
The property tax of about 80 per cent buildings in Dehradun has been submitted by their owners in Municipal Corporation of Dehradun (MCD). Besides, the MCD will improse a penalty on the building owners from April in case they fail to pay their property taxes by the end of this month.

Reportedly about 90,000 property owners have submitted the property tax in MCD so far. Last month, the percentage of property taxpayers was around 51.51 per cent but it took a huge leap this month.

According to the Dehradun municipal commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey, the property tax of about 80 per cent buildings of the city have been collected by the corporation and so far about Rs 43 crore has been submitted to MCD.

Pandey also informed that penalty will be imposed on those building owners who will not pay their property taxes by March 31. He said, “The corporation will prepare the list of all the registered buildings that have pending property tax within the first week of April. Subsequently, the notice will be issued to these properties with the penalty of around 15 per cent.” The municipal corporation has its own criteria of imposing penalty on the building owners who fail to pay the property tax by the due date. The penalty of Rs 100, Rs 1000, and Rs 5000 will be imposed on the area of the property up to 50 square metre, 200 square metre, and 400 square metre respectively. The penalty of Rs. 15000 will be imposed on the property of more than 400 square metre. However, if the submission of the property tax is late by 30 days, five per cent of the penalty will be levied as the delay fee by the corporation.

Title: Another corona suspect case in State
Article:
With the novel coronavirus COVID-19) spreading its wings across the globe rapidly, one more suspected case of the deadly virus was reported in Malkangiri district of Odisha.

The suspect has been advised by doctors to be under home quarantine following primary treatment at the District Headquarters Hospital.

Sources said that the COVID-19 suspect had recently returned to the State from the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON) temple in Kolkata. He is suspected to have come in contact with foreign nationals during his stay at the ISKCON temple.

Notably, all the persons suspected for coronavirus have been discharged from hospitals in the State after they tested negative for the virus.

In India, the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 has increased to 62 so far. The turmoil continues to widen across the world with 4,300 deaths and more than 1 lakh cases in 119 countries as of March 11.

Title: Dola Utsav is the swing fest for Puri Lords
Article:
Vrindavan is the place of Lord Krishna and Puri is the sacred ‘Dham’ of Lord Jagannath. When Vrindavan is famous for Lord Krishna’s Holi Utsav, many people across India do not know the importance of Dola Purnima or Dola Utsav in Puri.

As the scared Puri Dham is more known for Lord Jagannath’s annual Rath Yatra, Dola Utsav has not been highlighted as it should be.

Lord Jagannath is worshiped as “Dola Govinda” during the Dola Utsav. Dola means swing and utsav is festival. So this is the swing festival of Lord Jagannath which is celebrated with equal pomp and show as that of the festival in Brundavan.

Dola Purnima or ‘Basanta Utsav’ or spring festival in Odia almanac is observed on the full moon day or Poornima. ‘Krishna’ or “Dola Govinda’ becomes the center of attraction with various forms of worship all over Odisha.

Jagannath Dham is the pioneer of the Basant Utsav being celebrated across the State. Lord Balabhadra, Devi Subhadra, Lord Jagannath and Lord Sudarshan are decked up in Suna Besa or the golden attire on the Ratna Sinhasan. The godly attire is also called Raja Rajeswar Besa.

Lord’s representative or Govinda along with Sridevi are placed in Dola Bedi where devotees throw different colours on them. The six-day festival, also known as Dola Jatra in Odisha, begins from Falguna Dasami when idols of Lord Krishna are carried in decorated ‘Vimans’ (palanquin).

The devotees and carriers of Vimans are smeared with Abhira or dry colour. The idols are taken on procession and halt at the door step of villagers who worship Lord Krishna to get his blessings.

Like Dussehra, Dola Purnima is also celebrated as a festival marking victory of good over bad. According to Hindu mythology, demon Hiranya Kashyap attempted to kill his son Prahallad, a great devotee of Lord Krishna.

The demon king asked his sister Holika to sit in fire with Prahallad in order to kill him. Holika was blessed by God that she would not be burnt down in fire. However, Holika was burnt alive while Prahallad escaped from fire unhurt. The Holi festival, therefore, derived its name from Holika.

Title: Ruskin’s romance with reading blossomed in Shimla
Article:
Renowned writer Ruskin Bond has become synonymous with the Doon valley and Mussoorie as he has spent many long years in this region. Most of jos works talk about Doon and Mussoorie , especially Landour (Old Mussoorie) where he has been living since 1963.

However, there is another hill station, now in Himachal Pradesh, which has an important role in shaping his literary life and personality. When Bond was born in Kasauli in 1934, the town was in Punjab in colonial India. And when he studied at Bishop Cotton School in Shimla, it was again in the years when Shimla was in Punjab. However, today Himachal Pradesh takes pride in the fact that the great writer was born in this region and also did his schooling here.

I was at this famous hill station of Himachal Pradesh, its capital, recently for a literary event.

While I was talking to young students about Bond’s relationship with the hills and dales of Shimla, I realised that the manner in which his years there would have influenced him would have been indeed special.

I spoke to the writer about this and came to know about his days at Bishop Cotton School. “As a school boy at Simla’s Bishop Cotton School, I was made incharge of the Anderson Library there for my last two years in school.

This library contributed greatly to my love for reading and writing. I would allow myself to be transported to another world through the pages of Somerset Maugham, Hugh Walpole ,J.B.Priestley ,P.G.Wodehouse , J.M.Barrie,Compton Mackenzie,Dornford Yates and other successful novelists ,poets and playwrights of the 1930s and 40s,” said Bond while recalling those years.

“Another time that I was brought a trolley of books when I was down with jaundice in 1949 at school and was taken to Simla’s Ripon Hospital .It was a kind matron who, in a way, introduced me to O.Henry, Saqi and Barry Pain.

It was at Shimla that he read through a large number of books between the years 1947 and 1950 till he completed his schooling and came back to the Doon valley.”I think it would be fair to say that when I was a boy ,reading was my religion .

It helped me to discover my soul”, Bond says. In his book Confessions of a Book Lover he takes us into his inner world and gives us an insight into his childhood and adolescence when he developed a close relationship with the world of literature.

His earliest encounters with some of his favourite writers have been brought to us in this work which is a sort of sequel to his earlier Love among the Bookshelves .

He gives us a prelude before sharing with us some excerpt or chapter from the writings of the authors whom he has loved all his life. “These writers were important to me at various stages of my personal and writing life,” he says in his introduction to the book .

Talking to this correspondent ,he has often said that reading has always been a minority pastime. “When I was in school, out of 35 boys in my class, just three or four were readers.

Those days, the minority was in hundreds –now it may be in lakhs”, he says.By now, most of us know from Bond’s writings that he has been a great fan of Charles Dickens , especially David Copperfield with which he could identify himself easily .

Here he tells us that Nicholas Nickleby was also his favourite –“full of humor,pathos and memorable scenes”.It was in the winter of 1948 -49 that Bond, still a school boy, discovered Dickens in an old cupboard in Dehradun.

And indeed it is a great coincidence that Mussoorie, that has been Bond’s home for decades now, has a connection with Dickens as John Lang was a correspondent for Dickens’ Household Words while he(lang) lived in Mussoorie.

When Bond first visited Bengaluru in 1960, he came across the Select Bookshop of KBK Rao at MG Road ( now it is on Brigade Road) . He became friends with Rao and later with his son KKS Murthy who , even now, sends him handwritten lists of books that he thinks would interest Bond. The books keep piling up in his room and study at Ivy Cottage!

Bond says that he loves to discover “the unusual ,the little-known ,the forgotten , and even the eccentric…sometimes a little gem turns up or a neglected masterpiece”.

And he discovered many such gems at Bishop Cotton library in Shimla!He has written about his school friends in Shimla and fondly remembered them in many of his works.His bond with the Himalayas began in the Doon valley as well as during his years at Shimla.

Title: HC disposes of PIL against strike by General-OBC employees
Article:
The High Court of Uttarakhand has disposed of the public interest litigation filed against the strike by the general and OBC employees association. During the hearing on Wednesday, the advocate general SN Babulkar informed the court that talks are being held with the employees association to arrive at a solution. Following this, the strike will end in a few days, he said. Considering the information provided by the advocate general, the high court division bench of justice Ravi Vijaykumar Malimath and justice Sudhanshu Dhulia disposed of the public interest litigation.

It is pertinent to mention here that Dehradun resident Lalit Kumar had filed the public interest litigation stating that about 1.5 lakh government employees under the banner of the general and OBC employees association were on strike against the provision of reservation in promotions.

The petitioner had stated that the employees had been on strike since March 2 due to which various governmental works were being affected negatively. He had further contended that the employees on strike were violating the directions of the High Court and Supreme Court issued in various instances.

The striking employees should withdraw the strike and return to work failing which departmental action should be initiated against them, the petitioner had stated.

Title: ‘Sarkar Aapke Dwar’ programme at Jaridih
Article:
A public meeting was organised under the 'Sarkar Aapke Dwar' programme at Jaridih Block Headquarters under the chairmanship of DDC Ravi Ranjan Mishra. During this programme, information about public welfare schemes being run through various stalls in the interest of common people were given to the villagers .

During the programme stalls of various departments including Revenue , Labour Planning, Education, Health, Agriculture & Cooperation, Swachh Bharat Mission, MANREGA, PMAY, Social Security were established. Before the program started, crowds of villagers of Jaridih started gathering in these stalls and till the end of the programme, they kept getting the officials and personnel present in various stalls to solve their problems.

During the program, DDC Mishra said that houses will be allotted as per the data under PMAY. He also said that the summer season is about to begin therefore the entire previously damaged hand pump will be repaired so that people do not have to face water problems in summer.

During this program, Additional Collector Vijay Kumar Gupta, District Land Acquisition Officer James Surin, BDO SB Verma, Zonal Officer Monia Lata, District Education Superintendent Renuka Tigga, District Social Welfare Officer Manisha Vasta, Executive Engineer, personnel and other District officers were present.

Title: Union Church expresses gratitude to CM
Article:
The Church of Christ (Union Church) has thanked Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik for sanctioning a grant of Rs one crore from the State’s Special Problem Fund for creating new amenities in the church premises.

“It is a very kind and noble gesture and the worshippers of the church are extremely thankful to the Chief Minister for his concern for the minority communities,” the church said in a statement on Wednesday.

The church, located on Lokseva Marg at Unit-4, is one of the oldest ones in Bhubaneswar. Worshipers have been attending the worship service here since 1964.

The Christian community is also grateful to the State Government for allocating land for construction of the church in 1960. The church, built by the worshippers themselves, is today regarded as one of the premier ones of the State, the release said. The CM’s sanctioned amount would go a long way in meeting the infrastructural needs of the church, which has an expanding congregation, it added.

Title: New Jharsuguda flight time from March 29
Article:
Spice Jet and Alliance Air would change their flight schedule from the VSS Airport here to New Delhi from March 29.

As per the new schedule, Spice Jet flight will start from Delhi at 5.30 am and reach Jharsuguda at 7.25 am. It will leave Jharsuguda at 7.55 am to reach New Delhi at 9.50 am.

Spice Jet flight will leave Jharsuguda at 12.45 pm and reach Kolkata at 14.05 pm. It will start from Kolkata at 14.25 pm and reach Jharsuguda at 15.35 pm. The flights will leave Hyderabad at 10.35 am to reach Jharsuguda at 12.25 pm and leave Jharsuguda at 16.10 hrs to reach Hyderabad at 18.05 hrs.

Alliance Air flight will leave Kolkata at 7.45 am to reach Jharsuguda at 9.00 am. It will leave Jharsuguda at 9.25 am and reach Raipur at 10.55 am. From Raipur, it will again start at 11.20 am to reach Jharsuguda at 12.20 pm and again leaving Jharsuguda at 12.25 pm to reach Kolkata at 14.30 hrs.

However, passengers are dissatisfied over the new timings of the flights.

Title: Holi celebrated with traditional fanfare
Article:
Revellers from all age groups with their dyed cloths and faces enjoyed the festivals of colours; smeared ‘Gulal’, splashed Colour on each other and exchanged sweets as a mark of the festivity of unity and brotherhood.

With ‘Gulal’ and countless ‘Colours’, Holi was celebrated with traditional zeal across the Coal and Steel belt of Dhanbad-Bokaro on Tuesday amidst tight security, no untoward incidents were reported.

People visited friends and relatives, gifted sweets besides smearing ‘gulal’ on each other’s faces while children enjoyed the day most by spraying coloured water using water guns and water-filled balloons on others.

Though, this Holi, festival boozer, tipplers and occasional drinkers much enjoyed the festivity. The traditional drink bhang found losing its charm this Holi. More and more people found opting for liquor over the traditional drink.

Liquor sale ranks top this Holi, sold in ‘black’ in Bokaro and Chas. In a bid to sets the mood to make a splash with colours all brands sold for as high as 50 to 60 per cent from its print price here, said Shankar Prasad a tippler (resident of Marfari).

There is no control over the market, we are forced to pay a high price as its Holi, said Ishwar another buyer. “We have tried to contact excise department officials but none of them picked-up their mobile phone,” he added.

Meanwhile, Excise department sources said that there was an impressive increase in liquor supply and sales during Holi. There was an approximate 45 per cent increase in liquor sale during this festival, as compared to daily sales, he said.

According to the reports received over 21 people including one woman were injured in separate incidents in both districts on Holi; all accidents involved motorcyclists and most of the cases were drunk and drive.

On Monday evening people enthusiastically participated in the celebrations which began with lighting up of the bonfire known as ‘Holika Dahan’. The symbolic effigy of Holika, (the sister of Hiranyakashyapu-- the demon king) was set ablaze at several places.

Title: House mourns death of three former MLAs
Article:
The State Assembly on Wednesday mourned the deaths of three former MLAs, Bira Sipka, Bijay Kumar Nayak and Prahallad Behera, on Wednesday, the first day of its second phase of the ongoing Budget Session.

Brining Obituary References, Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik expressed deep grief and requested the Speaker to convey the House’s condolences to the bereaved families.

Leader of Opposition (BJP) Pradipta Kumar Nayak and Congress Legislature Party Leader Narasingha Mishra also mourned the deaths of the former members.

Expressing grief, Speaker Surjya Narayan Patro said the condolences of the House would be conveyed to the bereaved families. A one-minute silent prayer was observed for the departed souls.

Title: DA case: N’rangpur RTO arrested
Article:
Nabarangpur Regional Transport Officer (RTO) Ganeswar Konhar was arrested and forwarded to court and later remanded to judicial custody on March 9 in a disproportionate assets (DA) case.

On allegation of possession of huge disproportionate assets, his residential rented house at Nabarangpur, double-storied building (under construction) at Kandhamal, double-storied building at Kandhamal, house of associate at Rayagada in Gajapati district, flat at Kalarahanga, Bhubaneswar and office at Nabarangpur were simultaneously raided on March on 6.

Konhar was found in possession of assets disproportionate to his known sources of income to the tune of Rs 93,26,593 what he could not account for.

Title: Talks of politics of purity doesn’t suit JMM: BJP
Article:
The State BJP unit today reacted sharply on CM Hemant Soren’s statement in which he has said that the BJP that talks of politics of purity has conspired to topple the Government in Madhya Pradesh. State BJP Spokesperson Pratul Shahdeo today said that when JMM was running the Government with BJP in Jharkhand, Shibu Soren voted in favour of Congress in Parliament in Delhi. “Perhaps this is the case of purity of politics for the JMM. The JMM bribery scandal had written a new black chapter in parliamentary politics,” he said.

Pratul said the JMM should also remember that its ally Congress has imposed President's rule, dismissing elected State Governments more than one hundred times since independence. The Congress, the JMM's ally, contested against the Janata Dal (S) and Shiv Sena in Karnataka and Maharashtra and later formed a Government with these parties, leaving all moral values. Perhaps this is the definition of politics of purity from JMM's point of view, he added.

Title: Poornagiri Mela inaugurated in Tanakpur
Article:
The famous Poornagiri Mela was ceremoniously inaugurated by the Bharatiya Janata Party state president and MLA Banshidhar Bhagat here on Wednesday.

Praying for the welfare of the state on the occasion, Bhagat said that those who pray to the goddess with real devotion have their wishes fulfilled.

He recalled that this was the occasion when he was able to pay his obeisance to the goddess after his last visit here about 22 years ago. In view of the coronavirus risk, arrangements have also been made to check the people arriving here.

The local MLA Kailash Gahtodi appreciated the arrangements made for this historical fair by the administration. He assured the gathering that any devotee will not face any type of inconvenience while attending the fair and paying obeisance to the goddess. It is pertinent to mention here that in view of the coronavirus threat, the health department has facilitated health camp to check the people visiting this popuplar fair. The chief medical officer Dr RP Khanduri informed that a 14-member team of doctors has been provided to the temple committee.

Teams of six doctors have been deputed to Tanakpur and Banbasa to check the people. The visitors are being screened to check for symptoms of coronarivus as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of the disease in this fair which is visited by thousands of people.

Title: Cong to hold massive protest in Dehradun on March 18
Article:
The opposition Congress would organise a massive protest in Dehradun on March 18, the day the BJP government of Uttarakhand is completing three years in office.

The Trivendra Singh Rawat government is planning to hold programmes in all the assembly constituencies of the state on the day to commemorate three years in office. The vice president of Uttarakhand Congress, Surya Kant Dhasmana said that the party workers would hold a massive protest against the failure of Trivendra Singh Rawat Government on March 18.

He alleged that the BJP government of State has ceased wheel of development during its three years rule in the state. He said that the people of the state gave a massive mandate to the BJP in the year 2017 but the BJP has sabotaged faith people had reposed on it.Dhasmana said that the unemployment is at its highest in state and the recruitment process in the government departments has come to a standstill.

The Congress leader claimed that the BJP Government is immersed neck deep in corruption. “The irregularities in recently held examination of forest guards have proved extent to which the corruption has extended in the state,’’ he said. The Congress leader further said that farmers in state are under pressure and are forced to commit suicide.

Title: Five-fold increase in accident SOS to 108 ambulances on Holi
Article: A fivefold increase was witnessed in the accident related calls made to the 108 emergency ambulance service on the Holi festival. On a normal day, 15 to 20 accident related calls are received by the ambulance service but on the day of Holi, 71 calls of accidents on the roads of the state were received by the service. The general manager (GM) projects of the 108 ambulance service, Anil Sharma said that a total of 803 calls were received on the day of Holi and the service helped 624 people on the day. In Nainital district, one woman delivered baby in the ambulance. Giving details, Sharma said that 129 calls related with pregnancy, 71 calls related with accident, eight related with heart and 183 calls for other health issues were received on the day. He added that apart from them 232 calls related with the police were received by the emergency ambulance service that were transferred to the police control room.Sharma claimed that emergency service had taken all precautionary measures to meet any exigency on the day. In Dhari block of Nainital district, the health workers deployed in an ambulance ensured safe delivery of a baby in the ambulance. After the delivery, they admitted the new born and mother in the primary health centre (PHC), Dhari. In Dehradun district, the emergency service received 362 calls out of which 48 cases were related with pregnancy, 38 for road accidents, five were heart related while 78 were others. The service transferred 110 calls to the police control room.

Title: New 105 ft high flag pole in Jhanda Fair this year
Article:
After an interval of three years, the giant pole on which the flag (Jhanda) of Darbar sahib is hoisted, would be changed this year. On Wednesday, the devotees carried the new 105 feet high flag pole made from trunk of Sal tree to Darbar sahib amid chanting of slogans from the devotees.

Meanwhile the arrival of the devotees in the Darbar sahib for the Jhanda fair has gained momentum. Thousands of devotees from Punjab, Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh and other states reached Darbar Sahib on Tuesday evening.The officials of Darbar Sahib claimed that ten lakh devotees are expected to reach Dehradun on March 13 when the flag would be raised.

The Manager of Darbar Sahib’s Mela committee, Kailash Chand Juyal informed that Shri Darbar Sahib has made adequate arrangements for the stay of the devotees. Arrangements have been made at the various branches of Shri Guru Ram Rai Public Schools and other Dharamshalas of Dehardun. In view of the threat of Coronavirus (COVID-19), the authorities have placed two thermal scanners at the entrance of Darbar Sahib for screening of suspected patients. Meanwhile the work on stitching of gilafs has also gained momentum. The flag pole is covered with three type of covering, white or Sada Gilaf, Sanil Gilaf – 20 in numbers- and the outermost Darshani Gilaf. The Darshani Gilaf forms the outermost covering of the flag post and only one family is honored with the task of offering it.

Title: Police celebrate Holi after managing festival on Tuesday
Article:
While people were celebrating Holi on Tuesday, the police personnel across the state were on duty ensuring law and order and preventing the celebrations from going out of hand. A day later, on Wednesday, the police personnel celebrated Holi as is the tradition in the department, a day after the citizens celebrated the festival.

In Haridwar district, all police officers including the district’s senior superintendent of police Senthil Avoodai Krishnaraj S, SP (City) Kamlesh Upadhyay, CO, City, Abhay Pratap Singh and others along with the personnel participated in the Holi celebrations held at Police Line in Roshanabad.

During the revelry, SSP Senthil Avoodai Krishnaraj S said that the festival of Holi has special significance in Indian culture. This festival of colour also gives the message of the victory of good over evil. On this occasion, forgetting mutual differences, everyone celebrates the festival of love and celebration with goodwill. Police make all arrangements to provide protection to the citizens on Holi so that the people can celebrate the festival in a safe environment.

SP City Kamlesh Upadhyay said that the festival is also an opportunity to strengthen unity. The festival of colours is a festival of unity, brotherhood and strengthening harmony. Everyone should celebrate Holi with love and harmony.

Apart from the main police stations, policemen in all the police stations and posts in the districts including Jwalapur Kotwali, Nagar Kotwali, Kankhal police station, Mayapur police post and other sites applied colour on each other and exchanged festive greetings. Apart from the prevalent Holi songs, policemen danced enthusiastically to Garhwali songs.

Title: Training on corona held at PPT Hosp
Article:
A training programme on coronavirus COVID 2019 was organised at the PPT Hospital on Wednesday as per the instruction of the Union Government. PPT Deputy Chairman AK Bose declared the training session open in the presence of Dr P Panda, CMO, PPT.

Bose reiterated that the Paradip Port Trust would not leave any stone unturned to prevent the entry of any infectious disease, including the COVID-19 through this port. The port is fully prepared to tackle the unfolding scenario of the spreading of the viral disease affecting nearly 1,18,000 people globally. Bose emphasised on protection of the healthcare workforce while on duty so that they can take care of the others.

Imparting training to the gathering of principals/headmasters of local schools, representatives from stevedores and steamer agents, CISF and Coast Guard units, doctors and paramedics and representatives from various departments, Dr Panda highlighted practice of various precautionary and self-protection measures for prevention of the disease.

The meeting was concluded with a unanimous decision by the participants to sensitise others, in turn, on the basic public health measures to be adopted for prevention of the disease.

Title: Bipanna Sahayata Samiti holds fest
Article:
The annual function of Utkal Bipanna Sahayata Samiti (UBSS) was held on March 8 here. Governor Prof Ganeshi Lal inaugurated the function.

UBSS Secretary D Krushna Gopal gave a detailed account of the activities undertaken by the Samiti which was registered in 1982 immediately after the Cuttack flood.

He said the organisation participated in relief and rescue operations in 1999 Super Cyclone, Hudhud, Titli and Fani, besides earthquake of Bhuj in Gujarat and the thunder shower of Uttarakhand.

The organisation also joined plantation drive, computer literacy programme and runs hostels for IIT examination aspirants in collaboration of Shiksha Vikash Samiti, Odisha and Resonance, Bangaluru, he told.

For the last several years we have been providing different Seva during the Rath Yatra at Puri with free medicines and ambulance. The Samiti has provision to house patients and their attendants at Olatapur, Cuttack and Bhubaneswar, he informed.

Prof Lal was of very high opinion about the services by UBSS and gave different examples from Gita, Bhagabata, Vedas and other mythological books. Jagabandhu Mishra, former Editor, Rashtradeep, discussed how the volunteers reached the affected people even at odd hours.

The Governor gave away the Utkalmani Seva Samman to Padmacharan Nayak, a nonagenarian freedom fighter and Gandhian for his crusade against liquor.

Title: 93L families in NFSA, 83K in SFSS
Article:
As many 92,98,582 families comprising 3,24,73,370 people have been included in the National Food Security Act (NFSA) and 83,035 families comprising 3,12,311 people getting subsided rice under the State Food Security Scheme (SFSS).

Food Supplies and Consumer Welfare Minister Ranendra Pratap Swain informed this in the State Assembly in response to a question of BJP MLA Nityanand Gond on Wednesday.

The Minister informed that 86,612 families comprising 3,33,450 people have been included in the NFSA and 337 families comprising 1,274 people included in SFSWS in the Umarkote Assembly constituency area.

Title: Light showers with thunder, hail expected till Mar 17
Article:
The weather conditions being experienced by the residents of Jharkhand are likely to continue for the next few days as well. Light to moderate showers, thunderstorms and hail considered normal for this time of the year are being predicted till March 17 across the State.

“During the pre monsoon season which is normal for this time of the year, an anti cyclone has formed in the Bay of Bengal on March 10 because of which there is a lot of moisture incursion. There is a trough present in Rajasthan and its neighbouring states. A system of western disturbance is also active. Wind convergence is also present as on the upper and middle levels of the troposphere there are westerly winds while on the lower level easterly winds are present. All these factors together are causing rainfall across Jharkhand,” said Deputy Director, MET Centre Ranchi, Abhishek Anand.

As per the MET Observatory Centre, Ranchi for the next few days from March 12 to March 17, rainfall accompanied with thunder storms, lighting, gusty winds and hailstorms will occur in most parts of the State.

On March 12, light to moderate showers are predicted for north west, central and southern parts of the State.
